body: I would just remove it from the docs but keep it the code. People can already overwrite it if they want by that name and it's easy to support.

issue.title: Support Unicode literals in templates

repository.name: jinja
repository.description: A very fast and expressive template engine.

issue.body: Sometimes, it makes sense to format a character in a string literal-- ``` {{ "{0} is fantastic".format(user.full_name) }} ``` However, this will fail with a UnicodeEncodeError if user.full_name is a Unicode string with non-ASCII characters in it. Jinja2 does not support unicode string literals, so one must work around this problem like so-- ``` {{ "{0} is fantastic".decode("utf8").format(user.full_name) }} ``` This is icky. Could Jinja2 be changed in the future to support the Unicode literal? Our example code would look like this-- ``` {{ u"{0} is fantastic".format(user.full_name) }} ``` This mirrors what you would likely do in a Python script, which I think is what Jinja2 is going for. Aside: I think you might be wondering what the real use case is for this. Obviously, in the example I've used it would be easy to just write this: ``` {{ user.full_name }} is fantastic! ``` One example of where a unicode literal makes sense is encoding a querystring. For example, imagine we have a mailto link with some default body and subject text, which we want to format. This pattern makes sense: ``` {% set mailto_dict = { "body": "{0} is fantastic!".decode("utf8").format(user.full_name), "subject": "And this is some example text! Sincerely, {0}".decode("utf8").format(business.full_name), } %} Send an email ``` But all those `decode("utf8")` are icky. It would be much nicer to use a Unicode literal.

body: I'm not sure about the wisdom of encouraging the use of the old style `%` formatting mechanism. Python itself is moving away from it and encouraging use of the `format` method. Here's [an example](https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/string.html#format-examples) of the Python docs calling it the "old" syntax.
It's old in the sense that it came first, not that it's deprecated or discouraged.

@davidism No, it is discouraged. See the [`printf`-style String Formatting](https://docs.python.org/3//library/stdtypes.html#old-string-formatting) section of the docs:

> **Note:** The formatting operations described here exhibit a variety of quirks that lead to a number of common errors (such as failing to display tuples and dictionaries correctly). Using the newer [`str.format()`](https://docs.python.org/3//library/stdtypes.html#str.format) interface helps avoid these errors, and also provides a generally more powerful, flexible and extensible approach to formatting text.

[Python 3.1.5's docs](https://docs.python.org/release/3.1.5/library/stdtypes.html#old-string-formatting-operations) explicitly suggested it might be removed:

> **Note:** The formatting operations described here are obsolete and may go away in future versions of Python. Use the new [_String Formatting_](https://docs.python.org/release/3.1.5/library/string.html#string-formatting) in new code.

I'm not sure why the warning was toned down in newer versions.

As it stands if you want to support 2.x and 3.x, `%` is saner to use. `.format` introduces various problems with unicode handling in 2.x.

> Python 3.1.5's docs explicitly suggested it might be removed:

They just added `%` formatting back for bytes so I doubt this will be going anywhere. If it is, we can retrofit it.
Is there any plan to create built-in format filter which could be used in map() ?

@mitsuhiko What problems does `format` have with Unicode in 2.x? The only thing I can find is stuff about mixing bytes and text, to which the simplest, most well known answer is, "Don't do that." And according to [this](https://anonbadger.wordpress.com/2016/01/05/python2-string-format-and-unicode/), the problems of mixing them appear to go both ways; it's only the direction of the problems that changes depending on which you choose.
